top_comment.text: Doesn't the laminate wood on the stand get damaged by water?﻿
top_comment.author: Boxboymike

comments.text:
It does look like very good quality.  Of course if it is sealed then it 
will withstand substantial wear and exposure.  Thanks for the comment.  
Looking forward to the build!!!
comments.author: Boxboymike

comments.text:
+Boxboymike Its well sealed and high quality, looks to be very similar to 
the Elos stands (though with the metal frame instead of resting directly on 
the wood).  Almost every aquarium stand you buy at a store is made of 
laminated particle board but some are much higher quality then others. 
 Your typical stand is poorly sealed (some edges may even be entirely 
exposed) and will swell when they get wet.  Others like the Vertex stands 
use a much denser, stronger, and better sealed panels (not to mention the 
panels aren't actually supporting the weight of the tank).
comments.author: BulkReefSupplyCom

comments.author: BulkReefSupplyCom

top_comment.text:
You guys are awsome I love these videos. I am finally ready to start my own 
tank. What would you recommend to start out? It will be on a second floor 
so I dont want anything to big I was thinking a biocube but and advice 
would be awesome. Thanks!﻿
top_comment.author: Big Reefer

comments.text:
+Big Reefer There are a lot of great sizes in the nano category.  Most of 
us around here use the 16g Nuvo tanks.  A bit less water than something 
like the standard biocube but its nice to not have the hood.  Really gives 
you a lot of options in the future should you ever want to change your 
lights or something. 
http://www.bulkreefsupply.com/nano-16-nuvo-aquarium-innovative-marine-1.html
comments.author: BulkReefSupplyCom

comments.text:
The biocube will limit you in the area of lighting and filtration. A 29g or 
30g will be perfect to start with though. I highly recommend drilling the 
tank and using a sump with a nice skimmer (bubble magus is a more 
affordable brand). But if you don't go with a sump get a good brand hang on 
back skimmer like a aquaC remora. T5, LED, or Halide lights will work 
depending on what you prefer/can afford. This tank is great inspiration for 
a smaller reef: (http://www.nano-reef.com/featured/_/2009/makoypinoy-r27) 
Are you a member on Reef2Reef?

top_comment.text:
Whoot Whoot Cant wait to see how this one turns out I love clown fish I 
tried this in my 90 reef with a few anemones but where I think I went wrong 
was I got 1 Maroon Clown and then about 7  Ocellaris the Maroon Clown 
wasn't having any of it wouldn't let them near any of the anemones and 
would just beat the shit out of them till I had to take them all out before 
it started killing them  Live and learn lol still have the Maroon clown and 
hoping sometime soon can buy a small Maroon juvenile to mate it with 
crossing fingers ~SWC~﻿

captions.text:
Today on BRStv we are going to start a new
series based this tank Vertex gave us for

the BRS lobby. This is going to be the Vertex
120 Clownfish Harem build.

Hi I'm Ryan host of BRStv where each week
we cover a new topic related to reefing. This

week we are going to start a new tank build
for the lobby here at BRS. Vertex was kind

enough to donate a tank which looks pretty
sharp, especially the stand. We are going

to set this thing up and do a species only
tank filled with clowns, often referred to

as a harem.
It's typically not advisable to house more

than two clowns in an average sized tank.
While there are always exceptions to the rule

in most cases they will fight and eventually
kill each other until there are two left.

However there are ways to reduce this aggression
and create a healthy environment for multiple

clowns.
In fact it is part of clown's natural behavior

to live in colony with a single female, a
male and some smaller males or juveniles.

The female will be the largest and most aggressive,
followed by the dominant male. If the female

were to die the dominate male will change
sexes, begin growing and become the female

of the harem. The most aggressive of the remaining
males will become the dominate male and grow

male organs. Together their constant attention
to the other males prevents them from developing

sexually, something often referred to as psychophysical
castration.

We have researched this quite a bit, including
reading popular books on clowns, talking to

people in the industry who are authorities
on clowns as well as learning from other reefers'

experiences, particularly on forums. If you
are interested in doing this I would strongly

suggest taking the time to read one thread
in particular on Reef Central called 27 clowns,

27 months by Mobart. This is a 30-page plus
thread documenting their experience over many

years.
It is our goal to take everything that we've

learned and help others learn how to do this
successfully. The main components of success

seem to be providing enough habitat that they
don't feel the need to fight over it as well

as provide the less aggressive juveniles a
place to escape the aggression. Considering

the relatively small size of the aggression
circle a typical clown protects, this 120

gallon tank with a slew of anemones should
be adequate.

Another critical component is managing food
aggression, we'll develop a fairly heavy feeding

cycle which will likely be somewhat automated.
The increased feedings will require adequate

filtration techniques as well as a reliable
maintenance schedule to manage the nutrient

levels.
We are also going to start with fairly small

juveniles all from the same clutch where the
dominance hierarchy has already begun. This

obviously means we're going to stick to a
single species even though basically anyone

would prefer a verity. Lastly we will also
make sure the size of the harem is large enough

to distribute and diffuse aggression.
Today we are going to start by assembling

the tank and stand. The stand is really the
most impressive component of the system. Pretty

much every stand I have ever used has been
some type of plywood, pine or other wood supporting

the tank. The stand vertex sent over is built
using aluminum framing. We are going to go

ahead and assemble it so you can see the difference.
So this is what it looks like once we are

done before we get into what we like about
it let's take a look at a typical stand. This

pine stand is wobbly, really not attractive,
short and has a cross bar making it impossible

to get anything in or out. While it is absolutely
the most affordable, in my opinion a complete

miss on form and function for a typical reefer.
On the Vertex stand you can see the framing

is solid. This thing isn't going anywhere,
ever. The lament paneling is attractive and

sharp. You can take a close look at the edges
to see what a really solid job they have done.

You can see that this stand is much taller
and there is no cross bar which is going to

make it a hell of a lot easier to get equipment
in and out of the tank. To one up that, you

can even knock of the sides or remove the
doors at any time to get even more access.

This stuff isn't possible with other stands.
The rimless tank is also pretty sharp looking

and contains a glass reinforced overflow box
with a removable weir for easy cleaning. In

the next episode we are going get this thing
plumbed, full of water, set up the filtration

and get the rock cycling. If this is your
first time with us hit that subscribe button

because we do this every week and this series
is going to pretty cool . See ya next week
with another episode of BRStv.

title: BRS Vertex 120 Gallon Lobby Tank - EP 1: Clownfish Harem Tank #clownharemtank
